questions.question:
Question 1: You are working as a medical officer in a ceramic factory. What particle size of the dust 
inhaled would you be most concerned about?
questions.explanation:
Inhalation of dust particles in the size range of 0.5 to 3 microns is considered to be the most 
dangerous. It can lead to various occupational lung diseases called pneumoconioses. 695 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 2: Match the following causative agents with the disease caused by them:
questions.explanation: The correct match is: • Coal dust - Anthracosis • Hay dust - Farmer's lung • Cotton fibre - Byssinosis • Cane fibre - Baggasosis

questions.question:
Question 3: While working as an MO, you noticed an increased number of bagassosis patients in the area. 
Which of the following fungal control measures would you advise the sugarcane farmers to 
implement?
questions.explanation:
Fungal control on bagasse can be done by using 2% propionic acid and keeping the moisture 
content above 20%. Bagassosis is a hypersensitivity pneumonitis caused by inhaling bagasse dust contaminated by the 
fungus Thermoactinomyces sacchari. It is a reaction to the various antigens present in sugarcane 
molasses.

questions.question:
Question 4: A shipyard worker is diagnosed with asbestosis. Which of the following is false about his 
condition? 691 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: The symptoms usually occur after 5-10 years of exposure
options.c: Peribronchial fibrosis is a characteristic finding
options.d: The most dangerous form of asbestos is chrysolite type

questions.explanation:
Amphibole is the most dangerous form of asbestos. Chrysolite is a safer form of asbestos 
compared to amphibole. Asbestosis is a pneumoconiosis that occurs after 5-10 years of exposure to asbestos. It progresses 
even after the removal of contact with asbestos. Asbestosis affects the basal part of the lung 
causing diffuse peribronchial fibrosis. Sputum shows asbestos bodies, which are asbestos fibers coated with fibrin. The image given 
below shows asbestos bodies: 696 
Sold by @itachibot The complications that can occur are: • Pulmonary fibrosis • Carcinoma of the lung • Mesothelioma of the pleura • Malignancy of the gastrointestinal tract

questions.question:
Question 5: A patient presents with abdominal colic and constipation. On examination, pallor and blue 
stippled lines on gums are observed. What is the most common mode of exposure to this 
particular toxicity?
questions.explanation:
A patient presenting with constipation, pallor, and Burton's lines (blue stippled lines on gums), 
most likely has lead poisoning. The most common mode of exposure to lead toxicity is 
the inhalation of lead fumes. Lead poisoning occurs by lead exposure via the following modes: • Inhalation- lead fumes in gasoline and petroleum products • Ingestion- lead paint • Absorption through the skin– seen only with organic leads The most toxic forms of lead are lead oxide, lead carbonate, and lead arsenate. The least toxic 
form is lead sulfide.

questions.question: Question 6: Which of the following statements is true about lead poisoning?

options.a: Signs and symptoms occur when blood lead levels >70mcg/dL
options.c: Wrist drop is the earliest sign

questions.explanation:
The signs and symptoms of lead poisoning occur only when the blood lead levels exceed 
70mcg/dL, which is known as the threshold phenomenon. Lead poisoning is also known as plumbism/ Saturnism/ painter's colic. 697 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 8: 692 
Sold by @itachibot Barosinusitis is likely to be seen in which of the following patients?

options.a: A person who is suffering from mountain sickness
options.b: A patient Infected by gas-forming bacteria
options.c: A patient diagnosed with Aspergillus sinusitis
options.d: A diver who developed decompression sickness

questions.explanation:
Barosinusitis occurs in decompression sickness or Caisson's disease. It is due to the sudden 
expansion of air in the sinuses. It can be seen in: • Divers who ascend rapidly from deep-sea (high pressure) to the surface of the earth (low 
pressure) • Pilots of unpressurized aircraft or mountaineers who rapidly ascended from the surface of the 
earth (high-pressure zone) to a high altitude (low-pressure zone) Under high pressure, gases get compressed, and their solubility increases. When a person is in 
deep-sea (high-pressure zone) for a long time, an increased amount of nitrogen gets dissolved in 
his body. When he suddenly comes back to the surface (atmospheric pressure or a low-pressure 
zone), the solubility of gases decreases and they escape from the dissolved state forming nitrogen 
bubbles. These bubbles can cause sudden expansion of air in various parts of the body such as the middle 
ear (barotitis), sinuses (barosinusitis), beneath teeth (barodontalgia), intestinal loops (abdominal 
distension), and emphysema. Nitrogen bubbles can also cause chokes (dyspnoea), bends (joint pain), and prickles (nerve 
irritation). 698 
Sold by @itachibot The definitive treatment for Caisson's disease is recompression.

questions.question:
Question 9: Workers working at which of the following industries require periodical examination on a 
daily basis?
questions.explanation:
Workers handling irritant chemicals like dichromates require periodical examination on a daily 
basis. Most occupational exposures require an annual periodical examination. Certain exposures like 
lead, radon, and dyes require monthly periodical examination.

questions.question:
Question 10: Serial chest X-rays of an elderly man reveal progressive massive fibrosis. Which of the 
following pneumoconiosis is associated with this?
questions.explanation:
Progressive massive fibrosis (PMF) is associated with anthracosis. PMF classically develops in 
anthracosis and silicosis. Exposure to coal dust causes progressive lung injury called anthracosis. Initially, it manifests as 
simple coal worker pneumoconiosis, which occurs after exposure for 10–12 years and is reversible. 
Later, it can progress to progressive massive fibrosis (PMF) which is irreversible.

questions.question:
Question 11: Bronchoalveolar lavage from a patient with pneumoconiosis showed Micropolyspora faeni. 
What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Farmer's lung is a hypersensitivity pneumonitis caused by thermophilic actinomycetes 
like Saccharopolyspora rectivirgula (formerly known as Micropolyspora faeni). It occurs due to 
inhalation of moldy hay and grains causing an immunological reaction. Woodworker's lung is a hypersensitivity pneumonitis caused by Alternaria species, and Bacillus 
subtilis in persons exposed to oak, cedar, pine, and mahogany dust. Bird fancier's lung is caused by proteins derived from birds like pigeons and parakeets in persons 
exposed to their feathers and droppings. Malt worker's lung is caused by Aspergillus species in persons exposed to barley.

questions.question: Question 12: Which of the following does not belong to the 4 P's of occupational dermatitis?
questions.explanation:
Post-selection check-up does not belong to the 4 P's of occupational dermatitis. The 4 P's help in the prevention of occupational dermatitis, which include: • Pre-selection check-up • Protection • Personal hygiene • Periodic inspection 699 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 13: Which of the following statements is true about occupational cancer?

options.a: Age of incidence is same as compared to general population for the same cancer
options.b: The localization of the tumor is variable within a particular industry
options.c: The most common occupational cancer is squamous cell carcinoma
options.d: Onset of cancer does not occur after the person has left the industry

questions.explanation:
The most common occupational cancer is squamous cell carcinoma of the skin. It is associated 
with exposure to radiation, dyes, and coal tar. In occupational cancers, the age of incidence of cancer is earlier than that in the general 
population, affected by the same cancer type. The onset of cancer can occur even after leaving the 
industry. The localization of the cancer is remarkably constant for a particular industry.

questions.question:
Question 14: Cystoscopy performed on a patient with painless hematuria showed a fungating mass in the 
bladder. Exposure to all of the following agents can cause this disease except:
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of bladder carcinoma. Benzol does not cause bladder 
cancer, it causes leukemia. Bladder carcinoma is associated with exposure to aniline dyes like benzidine, 
beta-naphthylamines, auramine, magenta, and drugs like cyclophosphamide.

questions.question:
Question 15: A young woman is being evaluated for infertility. She gives a history of being employed in the 
printing industry. Exposure to which of the following is likely to cause this situation?
questions.explanation:
A woman working in the printing industry is likely to suffer from infertility due to lead toxicity. More industrial workers are exposed to lead than to any other toxic metal. Occupational exposure 
to lead is seen in several industries including the manufacturing of storage batteries, glass, 
shipbuilding, printing, potteries, and rubber industries. The effects of lead poisoning include abdominal colic, blue-line on the gums (Burton's line), 
stippling of red cells, anemia, wrist & foot drop, headache, and convulsions. In young or 
pregnant women, prolonged lead exposure can cause miscarriage, stillbirth, premature birth, and 
low birth weight.

questions.question: Question 16: Which of the following is not a personal protective equipment?
questions.explanation:
A lab coat is not a personal protective equipment. Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) are: • Gloves – protect hands. • Gowns/ aprons – protect skin and clothing. • Masks protect the mouth/nose and respirators protect the respiratory tract from airborne 
infectious agents. • Goggles – protect eyes. • Face shields – protect face, mouth, nose, and eyes. 700
